info.title: Item List API
info.description: A list of items of any sort—for example, Top 10 Movies About Weathermen, or Top 100 Party Songs. Not to be confused with HTML lists, which are often used only for formatting.

parameters.name: q
parameters.description: Keyword search for item

parameters.name: additionaltype
parameters.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

parameters.name: alternatename
parameters.description: An alias for the item.

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: A short description of the item.

parameters.name: image
parameters.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

parameters.name: itemlistelement
parameters.description: For itemListElement values, you can use simple strings (e.g. "Peter", "Paul", "Mary"), existing entities, or use ListItem.        Text values are best if the elements in the list are plain strings. Existing entities are best for a simple, unordered list of existing things in your data. ListItem is used with ordered lists when you want to provide additional context about the element in that list or when the same item might be in different places in different lists.        Note: The order of elements in your mark-up is not sufficient for indicating the order or elements.  Use ListItem with a 'position' property in such cases.

parameters.name: itemlistorder
parameters.description: Type of ordering (e.g. Ascending, Descending, Unordered).

parameters.name: mainentityofpage
parameters.description: Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the item.

parameters.name: numberofitems
parameters.description: The number of items in an ItemList. Note that some descriptions might not fully describe all items in a list (e.g., multi-page pagination); in such cases, the numberOfItems would be for the entire list.

parameters.name: potentialaction
parameters.description: Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

parameters.name: recipeinstructions
parameters.description: A step or instruction involved in making the recipe.

parameters.name: sameas
parameters.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

parameters.name: track
parameters.description: A music recording (track)—usually a single song. If an ItemList is given, the list should contain items of type MusicRecording.  Supersedes tracks.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: URL of the item.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique id for item

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique id for item

parameters.name: additionaltype
parameters.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

parameters.name: alternatename
parameters.description: An alias for the item.

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: A short description of the item.

parameters.name: image
parameters.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

parameters.description: Type of ordering (e.g. Ascending, Descending, Unordered).

parameters.name: mainentityofpage
parameters.description: Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the item.

parameters.name: numberofitems
parameters.description: The number of items in an ItemList. Note that some descriptions might not fully describe all items in a list (e.g., multi-page pagination); in such cases, the numberOfItems would be for the entire list.

parameters.name: potentialaction
parameters.description: Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

parameters.name: recipeinstructions
parameters.description: A step or instruction involved in making the recipe.

parameters.name: sameas
parameters.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

parameters.description: A music recording (track)—usually a single song. If an ItemList is given, the list should contain items of type MusicRecording.  Supersedes tracks.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: URL of the item.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique id for item

description.description: Indicates the current disposition of the Action.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
The direct performer or driver of the action (animate or inanimate). e.g. *John* wrote a book.
An alias for the item.
A short description of the item.

The endTime of something. For a reserved event or service (e.g. FoodEstablishmentReservation), the time that it is expected to end. For actions that span a period of time, when the action was performed. e.g. John wrote a book from January to *December*.Note that Event uses startDate/endDate instead of startTime/endTime, even when describing dates with times. This situation may be clarified in future revisions.
For failed actions, more information on the cause of the failure.
An Offer which must be accepted before the user can perform the Action. For example, the user may need to buy a movie before being able to watch it.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
The object that helped the agent perform the action. e.g. John wrote a book with *a pen*.
The location of for example where the event is happening, an organization is located, or where an action takes place.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The name of the item.

The object upon the action is carried out, whose state is kept intact or changed. Also known as the semantic roles patient, affected or undergoer (which change their state) or theme (which doesn't). e.g. John read *a book*.
Other co-agents that participated in the action indirectly. e.g. John wrote a book with *Steve*.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
The result produced in the action. e.g. John wrote *a book*.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

The startTime of something. For a reserved event or service (e.g. FoodEstablishmentReservation), the time that it is expected to start. For actions that span a period of time, when the action was performed. e.g. John wrote a book from *January* to December.Note that Event uses startDate/endDate instead of startTime/endTime, even when describing dates with times. This situation may be clarified in future revisions.
Indicates a target EntryPoint for an Action.
URL of the item.

A property-value pair representing an additional characteristics of the entitity, e.g. a product feature or another characteristic for which there is no matching property in schema.org. Note: Publishers should be aware that applications designed to use specific schema.org properties (e.g. http://schema.org/width, http://schema.org/color, http://schema.org/gtin13, ...) will typically expect such data to be provided using those properties, rather than using the generic property/value mechanism.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
Physical address of the item.
The overall rating, based on a collection of reviews or ratings, of the item.
An alias for the item.
Alumni of an organization. Inverse property: alumniOf.

name.type: text or  place or  geoshape or  administrativearea

description.description: The geographic area where a service or offered item is provided. Supersedes serviceArea.
description.type: text or  place or  geoshape or  administrativearea

description.description: An award won by or for this item. Supersedes awards.

A short textual code (also called "store code") that uniquely identifies a place of business. The code is typically assigned by the parentOrganization and used in structured URLs. For example, in the URL http://www.starbucks.co.uk/store-locator/etc/detail/3047 the code "3047" is a branchCode for a particular branch.
The brand(s) associated with a product or service, or the brand(s) maintained by an organization or business person.
A contact point for a person or organization. Supersedes contactPoints.
The basic containment relation between a place and one that contains it. Supersedes containedIn. Inverse property: containsPlace.
The basic containment relation between a place and another that it contains. Inverse property: containsPlace.
The currency accepted (in ISO 4217 currency format).

A relationship between an organization and a department of that organization, also described as an organization (allowing different urls, logos, opening hours). For example: a store with a pharmacy, or a bakery with a cafe.
A short description of the item.
The date that this organization was dissolved.
The Dun & Bradstreet DUNS number for identifying an organization or business person.
Email address.
Someone working for this organization. Supersedes employees.
Upcoming or past event associated with this place, organization, or action. Supersedes events.
The fax number.
A person who founded this organization. Supersedes founders.
The date that this organization was founded.
The place where the Organization was founded.
The geo coordinates of the place.

The Global Location Number (GLN, sometimes also referred to as International Location Number or ILN) of the respective organization, person, or place. The GLN is a 13-digit number used to identify parties and physical locations.
A URL to a map of the place. Supersedes map, maps.
Indicates an OfferCatalog listing for this Organization, Person, or Service.
Points-of-Sales operated by the organization or person.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
The International Standard of Industrial Classification of All Economic Activities (ISIC), Revision 4 code for a particular organization, business person, or place.
The official name of the organization, e.g. the registered company name.
The location of for example where the event is happening, an organization is located, or where an action takes place.
An associated logo.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
A pointer to products or services offered by the organization or person. Inverse property: offeredBy.

A member of an Organization or a ProgramMembership. Organizations can be members of organizations; ProgramMembership is typically for individuals. Supersedes musicGroupMember, members. Inverse property: memberOf.
An Organization (or ProgramMembership) to which this Person or Organization belongs. Inverse property: member.
The North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code for a particular organization or business person.
The name of the item.
The number of employees in an organization e.g. business.

The opening hours for a business. Opening hours can be specified as a weekly time range, starting with days, then times per day. Multiple days can be listed with commas ',' separating each day. Day or time ranges are specified using a hyphen '-'.- Days are specified using the following two-letter combinations: Mo, Tu, We, Th, Fr, Sa, Su.- Times are specified using 24:00 time. For example, 3pm is specified as 15:00. - Here is an example: <time itemprop="openingHours" datetime="Tu,Th 16:00-20:00">Tuesdays and Thursdays 4-8pm</time>. - If a business is open 7 days a week, then it can be specified as <time itemprop="openingHours" datetime="Mo-Su">Monday through Sunday, all day</time>.
The opening hours of a certain place.
Products owned by the organization or person.
The larger organization that this organization is a branch of, if any. Supersedes branchOf. Inverse property: subOrganization.
Cash, credit card, etc.
A photograph of this place. Supersedes photos.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
The price range of the business, for example $$$.
A review of the item. Supersedes reviews.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
A pointer to products or services sought by the organization or person (demand).
A relationship between two organizations where the first includes the second, e.g., as a subsidiary. See also: the more specific 'department' property. Inverse property: parentOrganization.
The Tax / Fiscal ID of the organization or person, e.g. the TIN in the US or the CIF/NIF in Spain.
The telephone number.
URL of the item.
The Value-added Tax ID of the organization or person.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
An alias for the item.
A short description of the item.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The name of the item.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
URL of the item.
Indicates the current disposition of the Action.

Other co-agents that participated in the action indirectly. e.g. John wrote a book with *Steve*.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
The result produced in the action. e.g. John wrote *a book*.

The startTime of something. For a reserved event or service (e.g. FoodEstablishmentReservation), the time that it is expected to start. For actions that span a period of time, when the action was performed. e.g. John wrote a book from *January* to December.Note that Event uses startDate/endDate instead of startTime/endTime, even when describing dates with times. This situation may be clarified in future revisions.
Indicates a target EntryPoint for an Action.
URL of the item.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
An alias for the item.
A short description of the item.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
The WebSite or SoftwareApplication where the interactions took place.
The number of interactions for the CreativeWork using the WebSite or SoftwareApplication. The most specific child type of InteractionCounter should be used.  Supersedes interactionCount.
The Action representing the type of interaction. For up votes, +1s, etc. use LikeAction. For down votes use DislikeAction. Otherwise, use the most specific Action.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The name of the item.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
URL of the item.
The number of interactions for the CreativeWork using the WebSite or SoftwareApplication.

A property-value pair representing an additional characteristics of the entitity, e.g. a product feature or another characteristic for which there is no matching property in schema.org. Note: Publishers should be aware that applications designed to use specific schema.org properties (e.g. http://schema.org/width, http://schema.org/color, http://schema.org/gtin13, ...) will typically expect such data to be provided using those properties, rather than using the generic property/value mechanism.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. The direct performer or driver of the action (animate or inanimate). e.g. *John* wrote a book.
An alias for the item.
A short description of the item.

The endTime of something. For a reserved event or service (e.g. FoodEstablishmentReservation), the time that it is expected to end. For actions that span a period of time, when the action was performed. e.g. John wrote a book from January to *December*.Note that Event uses startDate/endDate instead of startTime/endTime, even when describing dates with times. This situation may be clarified in future revisions.
For failed actions, more information on the cause of the failure.
Upcoming or past event associated with this place, organization, or action. Supersedes events.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
The language of the content or performance or used in an action. Please use one of the language codes from the IETF BCP 47 standard. Supersedes language.
The object that helped the agent perform the action. e.g. John wrote a book with *a pen*.
The location of for example where the event is happening, an organization is located, or where an action takes place.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.

Other co-agents that participated in the action indirectly. e.g. John wrote a book with *Steve*.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
A sub property of participant. The participant who is at the receiving end of the action.
The result produced in the action. e.g. John wrote *a book*.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

The startTime of something. For a reserved event or service (e.g. FoodEstablishmentReservation), the time that it is expected to start. For actions that span a period of time, when the action was performed. e.g. John wrote a book from *January* to December.Note that Event uses startDate/endDate instead of startTime/endTime, even when describing dates with times. This situation may be clarified in future revisions.
Indicates a target EntryPoint for an Action.
URL of the item.
The identifier for the account the payment will be applied to.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
An alias for the item.
The time interval used to compute the invoice.

An entity that arranges for an exchange between a buyer and a seller.  In most cases a broker never acquires or releases ownership of a product or service involved in an exchange.  If it is not clear whether an entity is a broker, seller, or buyer, the latter two terms are preferred. Supersedes bookingAgent.
A category for the item. Greater signs or slashes can be used to informally indicate a category hierarchy.
A number that confirms the given order or payment has been received.
Party placing the order or paying the invoice.
A short description of the item.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The minimum payment required at this time.
The name of the item.
The order is being paid as part of the referenced Invoice.
The date that payment is due. Supersedes paymentDue.
The name of the credit card or other method of payment for the order.
An identifier for the method of payment used (e.g. the last 4 digits of the credit card).
The status of payment; whether the invoice has been paid or not.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

The service provider, service operator, or service performer; the goods producer. Another party (a seller) may offer those services or goods on behalf of the provider. A provider may also serve as the seller. Supersedes carrier.
The Order(s) related to this Invoice. One or more Orders may be combined into a single Invoice.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
The date the invoice is scheduled to be paid.
The total amount due.
URL of the item.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
An alias for the item.
The availability of this item—for example In stock, Out of stock, Pre-order, etc.
A short description of the item.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The name of the item.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
Relates a term (i.e. a property, class or enumeration) to one that supersedes it.
URL of the item.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
An alias for the item.
A short description of the item.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

For itemListElement values, you can use simple strings (e.g. "Peter", "Paul", "Mary"), existing entities, or use ListItem.        Text values are best if the elements in the list are plain strings. Existing entities are best for a simple, unordered list of existing things in your data. ListItem is used with ordered lists when you want to provide additional context about the element in that list or when the same item might be in different places in different lists.        Note: The order of elements in your mark-up is not sufficient for indicating the order or elements.  Use ListItem with a 'position' property in such cases.
Type of ordering (e.g. Ascending, Descending, Unordered).
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The name of the item.

The number of items in an ItemList. Note that some descriptions might not fully describe all items in a list (e.g., multi-page pagination); in such cases, the numberOfItems would be for the entire list.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
A step or instruction involved in making the recipe.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
A music recording (track)—usually a single song. If an ItemList is given, the list should contain items of type MusicRecording.  Supersedes tracks.
URL of the item.
